issues.description: The template repository has an internal method-name mismatch for accessing an ingredient's quantity: Stock.java calls stockIngredient.getQuantity(), but StockIngredient.java in the template defines retrieveQuantity() instead of getQuantity(). This causes the template to be non-compilable and contradicts the problem statement's requirement to provide getters for all private fields. The solution repository uses getQuantity(), which shows the intended API. Students will be blocked or confused because they must either change Stock or add the expected getter, but the template should already present a consistent API.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template API consistent by providing the expected getter name. Either rename retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity() in template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/StockIngredient.java, or add a public getQuantity() method that delegates to retrieveQuantity(). Ensure Stock.java and other classes use getQuantity() so the template compiles and matches the problem description and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement asks students to "add getters for all the private fields" (implying standard getter names like getQuantity). The template repository's StockIngredient class exposes the quantity via a method named retrieveQuantity(), while other template files (Stock, Main) and the solution repository use getQuantity(). This inconsistent identifier (retrieveQuantity vs getQuantity) breaks the conceptual mapping for the simple "add getters" requirement, causes compilation mismatches within the template (Stock and Main call getQuantity but StockIngredient only provides retrieveQuantity), and forces students to guess whether to add getQuantity or change all usages to retrieveQuantity.
issues.suggested_fix: Standardize the getter name for the quantity field to getQuantity across all artifacts. Concretely, rename retrieveQuantity() in the template's StockIngredient.java to getQuantity() (or add a getQuantity() delegating to retrieveQuantity) so that Stock, Main, the problem statement expectations, and the solution all use the same identifier. This preserves the intended educational instruction to "add getters" and removes the compilation/mental-mapping friction.
